My genuine opinion:


Everything changes with the perspective. The view on what we see ,narrates us the story that way and finally we get a conclusion. The so called term "moral values" changes its meaning. And we think we are right. And our mind is like "I am right that's it. I don't want anyone teach me. "


For example.... 

When watching reels I came across a video.... 

"A lady was going to dip ps 5 of his husband knowing that it is the only income sources but still she dips it telling him that he did not give her time and he always goes through his ps5. "


Now after watching that kind of reels the first thing comes to mind is .... 

"RA*ISTS ARE NOT THAT BAD"

"RA*E HER"...... etc.. 

Now why does that come to my mind...

The reasons are..... 


1. We are not godly beings.. Who don't even flicker in their worst time and do those things that should be done disrupting all kind of emotions. 


2. Human brains " Moral Value" alter with every perspective with every angle of view, circumstances. 


3.(Specific Point) When I saw that reel that idea came to my mind because I am flustered of all these things that women get extra opportunity in every field than men. In that case the reel is just a spark to the devastating fire. As I saw the video I did not think anything else. I just thought... 

"How did she dare to dip the ps 5 in the pool"

"What if the roles are reversed"

"What kind of suppliment will he get now. He can't apply a case on her. If he did so he will got a divorce.. And the wife will  get an alimony... Which is husband's loss "

"What is the husband's mental state now... How upset he is.. "


That's the ingredients that made me think those lines I mentioned at the top.... 


So the main thing is the question you asked "kya rape galat hai " Changes with the angle of view... 


May everyone can't say that thinking that society could spot him as a pshycho but that's the true thing that passes in his mind at such perspectives. 


Hope @dhruvrathee read the whole comment of me... And give me a serious reply about my series of thoughts.

All valid points but this only covers one side of the crime. This type of crime is mostly reported as being done by men against women but that is not the only case, It happens the other way around as well. If you tip the scale in one direction it will lead to a new problem. If a woman initiates or starts teasing a man younger than her, should she be held accountable for harassment equally as a man would have been in a similar situation? If a gang of women rape a young man they should be punished equally by law. Do you think women don't tease and bully men whom they consider weaker than themselves? Having laws strict only for men will give certain women a chance to start abusing the system and blame innocent men at work for sexual harassment if they disagree with them or rejects their sexual advances. It all seems far fetched to an unaware person but is very much the reality. In future this will create distance between normal men and women, because women will be afraid of men harassing them and men will be afraid of women falsely accusing them of rape.

The idea that boys or men are negatively affected by girls or women wearing short clothes is a harmful stereotype that can perpetuate damaging attitudes and behaviors. Here's the truth:

1. Wearing short clothes is a personal choice, and girls and women have the right to decide how they want to dress.
2. Boys and men are capable of controlling their thoughts, feelings, and actions. They can respect others' boundaries and choices, regardless of clothing.
3. Objectifying or harassing someone based on their clothing is never acceptable. It's essential to promote respect, consent, and healthy relationships.
4. Let's focus on teaching boys and men about respect, boundaries, and healthy attitudes towards others, rather than blaming girls' and women's clothing choices.

Remember, it's about promoting a culture of respect, understanding, and consent!тЭд

Dear Sir Ji,I am writing to bring to your urgent attention a grave issue concerning the Community Health Officers (CHOs) of the UP NHM, who are currently on strike at the NHM office in Lucknow.These CHOs, many of whom are young women, have been tirelessly working in various districts far from their homes. After joining the department unmarried, many of them have now settled into married life. However, the absence of a transfer policy within the UP NHM has left them stranded in districts far from their sasural, causing significant personal and family distress.These women are not just facing isolation in unfamiliar cities with inadequate salaries, but are also vulnerable to exploitation and harassment by NHM officers. The lack of support and a clear transfer policy is taking a severe toll on their mental and emotional well-being, leading to extreme cases where some have tragically taken their own lives.This is a serious issue that demands immediate attention. I urge you to use your platform to bring this to light and advocate for these women, who are in desperate need of a fair and humane transfer policy. They need your voice to ensure their safety and dignity.Thank you for considering this crucial issue.

In the end, all the typical society really focusses on is woman, procreation and religion.

Subject: Request for a Video on Violence Against Muslim Vendors in Odisha and Murshidabad

Dear Dhruv sir ,

I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to bring to your attention a deeply concerning issue that has recently come to light. There have been reports of violence against Muslim vendors in Odisha and Murshidabad, where these individuals are being harassed, assaulted, and even asked to show their identification, such as Aadhaar cards, by common people.

Such incidents are not only alarming but also pose a serious threat to the social fabric of our society. The targeting of individuals based on their religion is an issue that needs to be addressed urgently, and I believe that your platform can play a significant role in bringing this to the forefront.

Given your expertise in creating insightful and impactful content, I would like to request you to make a video on this topic. Your ability to research and present such sensitive issues with clarity and depth would help raise awareness and possibly influence positive change.

Thank you for considering this request. I am confident that your coverage of this issue would be invaluable in spreading awareness and fostering a more inclusive and just society.

Looking forward to your response.

Islam legalises domestic violence against women. The verses of the Quran relating to permissibility of domestic violence is Surah 4:34. Shari'a law provisions are discriminatory against women from a human rights.Shari'a law, a woman's testimony is worth half of a man's before a court. Sharia courts permit girls less than 18 years old to marry.Sharia law  allows a rapist to escape punishment by marrying his victim, while in other cases the victim who complains is often prosecuted with the crime of Zina (adultery). woman's inheritance is unequal and less than a man's, and dependent on many factors.[Quran 4:12]A daughter's inheritance is usually half that of her brother's.[Quran 4:11] slave women were not granted the same legal rights. Sharia recognizes the basic inequality between master and women slave, between free women and slave women, between believers and non-believers, as well as the as the non believers as well as their non equal rights Sharia authorized the institution of slavery, using the words abd (slave) and the phrase ma malakat aymanukum ("that which your right hand owns") to refer to women slaves, seized as captives of war. Under classical Islamic law, Muslim men could have sexual relations with female captives and slaves without her consent. Slave women under sharia did not have a right to own property, right to free movement or right to consent. Sharia provides religious foundation for enslaving non-Muslim women (and men), as well as encouraged slave's manumission. However, manumission required that the non-Muslim slave first convert to Islam. Non-Muslim slave women who bore children to their Muslim masters became legally free upon her master's death, and her children were presumed to be Muslims as their father.
